column11: Review Text

column8: Ancient Beauty and History at Medirigiriya Vatadage
column11: Medirigiriya Vatadage is one of the best-preserved ancient Buddhist monuments in Sri Lanka, believed to date back to the Anuradhapura period. The circular structure with tall stone pillars once protected a sacred relic. Today, the calm atmosphere, Buddha statues, and fine stone carvings allow visitors to feel the deep history of the place. It‚Äôs peaceful, uncrowded, and perfect for anyone interested in Sri Lankan heritage

column8: Medirigiriya Vatadageya: A Hidden Historical Gem
column11: If you're a history or architecture enthusiast, Medirigiriya Vatadageya is an absolute must-visit. Tucked away in a serene and lesser-explored part of Sri Lanka, this ancient circular relic house is a masterpiece of Buddhist architecture and an incredible testament to the island's rich heritage. The site's highlight is its symmetrical design, featuring a central stupa surrounded by finely carved stone pillars and four Buddha statues facing the cardinal directions. The craftsmanship is breathtaking, with intricate carvings and inscriptions that transport you back to a time when spirituality and artistry flourished together. The location adds to its charm ‚Äì perched on a low hill amidst tranquil surroundings, it feels like stepping into a meditative sanctuary. Unlike the busier sites in Polonnaruwa, Medirigiriya offers peace and an opportunity to explore at your own pace without large crowds. Practical tips: - Wear comfortable shoes, as there‚Äôs a bit of walking involved. - Visit in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the midday heat. - Bring water and a hat, as facilities nearby are limited. Overall, Medirigiriya Vatadageya is a hidden gem that deserves more attention. It's perfect for those looking to connect with Sri Lanka's spiritual and historical roots in a tranquil setting. Highly recommended!
Another vatadage that I really liked and impressed me especially for its configuration and its story. Recommendation a thorough visit and you will love it too.

An ancient Buddhist monastery, the Vatadage currently house the ruins of several structures, some of which are built on rocks. The main feature is the circular temple with pillars and 4 statues of Buddha, wonderfully preserved for being so old. There are several other structures including more Buddha statues and a stupa built on rocks. A bit further up the same premises, there is an ancient hospital - this was adjoining a forest area from which a deer family emerged - a very pleasant surprise! We went on a weekday so there maybe 6 other people in total so we had the whole place to ourselves. The site is charming and serene, with a couple of ponds and the view from the top of the structure very pretty. I believe there is no entrance fee (there wasn't when we went) and there was no parking charge either. But keep in mind, this is a fair bit away from the main sites of Polonnaruwa/Dambulla etc, so it may not be getting a lot of tourists. However, if you have some time, and feel up for a (slightly) off the beaten path trek, this is a charming place to visit. Accessibility wise  -  there are a few steps to climb, but generally an easy visit.

This is known as the most beautiful and well preserved vatadageya complex in Sri Lanka. You can see plenty of vatadageya structures in Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa ancient kingdoms. But none is as beautiful or preserved as this. Since it is located but away from Polonnaruwa ancient ruins , not many people visit here. But this is worth to visit. Recommended to visit in early mornings or late evenings as it is very hot in day time. We went close to noon and it was very hard to walk on those stone foot paths as well.

This is located near by Polonaruwa, starred dating back to over 2000 years and sprayed over 100 acres. Other main feature of Monastery is a hospital that was quite advanced. You need at least a half day to visit all. But avoid hot üî• sunny time. Free to enter but charge a little for parking. Please don't damage anything and don't litter when you visiting.
Very Beautiful Ancient Buddhist Structure Builded using Rocks. This place located in a middle of a Forest but easy to Visit. Calm and quiet place.
Interesting, but really not much to see. Other tourists were very busy taking selphies, which rather spoil the scene.
Religion & architecture come together in an amazing combo to create these wonderful experiences! A must visit...

column8: Nice but take your time cos there are many tourists (Photobombs)
column11: Very hot going in mid day, so maybe go when it is more cloudy or early in the morning :) Recommend that you go along with Wikipedia (better than some of the guides) In my week-long in Sri Lanka I didnt feel pestered by touts and salespeople, but here I met a couple.

This is a world heritage site and a must visit in Polonnaruwa. Well preserved site. All the ruins are in one location and it is easy to walk around from one ruin to the other. Highly recommend taking a guided tour
Situated in north western province, in Polonnaruwa district. About 15 km from Hingurakgoda. It's an ancient place of worship.

Medirigiriya vatadage  is a very famous ancient building built in pre Christian times later restored by the Department of Archeology. It‚Äôs a building which completely houses a Stupa. Once it was hidden behind the thick jungles and found by Mr HCP Bell in 1897. Now it‚Äôs fully restored to its full architectural beauty by the enthusiastic Archeologists. It is surrounded by few other buildings including an old hospital.
very interesting place in polonnaruwa,ruins with histrical value and buddha statue,behind the place there was a deer family,very much interestng

So nice to visit sites where we only meet a few people, and all of these are friendly Sri Lankan people. Interesting place to visit and get a sense of the amazing history without the crowds you will meet at the popular destinations.

Medirigiriya Vatadage and surrounding area are ruins of a monastery in Polonnaruwa. The earliest reference recorded about this monastery is in 2 century AD. Nice architecture and the best place to visit if you love to see historical places.

The main attraction once housed religious relics and has pillars arranged in 3 concentric rings. It is located in Polonnaruwa ancient kingdom with plenty of exotic wildlife and worth a visit if you‚Äôre in the area.

My Sri Lankan friend told me about this site. It was a truly beautiful place to visit. The atmosphere was very chilled. Not overcrowded by a lot of tourists and no feeling of rushing on the site. When I went there, I was the only tourist and the rest of people seemed all local people enjoying their own time. This site is very compact compared with Polonnaruwa. I had visited polonnaruwa previously on another occasion. So, it was ok for me as a tourist. If it had been first time visit to Sri Lanka, I might have felt this place didn‚Äôt have many to see compared with polonnaruwa by considering all effort to get there. I went there from Habarana by taking a bus to Hingurakgoda. Then tuk tuk for return journey. There is a parking fee (very small) if a tuk tuk waits for you. But as other people said, there seems to be a bus to get there from Hingurakgoda too. Very chilled and beautiful place to visit if you have extra day and time.

Medirigiriya Vatadage (the Buddhist structure from Vatadage) predates the kingdom of Polonnaruwa, as the first reference to it was found in chronicles from the time of king Kanittha Tissa (192-194) of the Anuradhapura Era. It is one of the most attractive, the most beautiful and the most photogenic structures of the Polonnaruwa Archeological Site, it is often associated with the glorious past of the country and we consider ourselves lucky for the chance of visiting it ...
This historical site is amazing. Its an unbelievable and very beautiful ancient time build temple. Less tourist, but very  worth to see, also not too far from Polonnaruwa ancient site.

Nice place to visit, not many tourists around. To get there from Polonnaruwa you can take a tuk tuk or if you got time and if you're on a budget, you can take the bus from Polonnaruwa to Hingurakgoda and another one to Medirigiriya. Takes some time but it's worth it!

Its a buddist monastery which was built at 300 BC and functioned until 1300 AD. The person or the people who built this is unknown. Its said that there was a well developed hospital probably for buddist monks at this place. Later it was destroyed by various invaders from south India. It comprised of ruins which depicts the skills of ancient Sinhalese stone carvers and craftsmen.  Buddist statues and huge stone pillars still holds their majestic nature. Place is very calm and quite and a must visit place if you are interested in visiting ancient ruins of Srilanka.

Huge monument with majestic columns online that once held up a roof that has long since been destroyed. Beautiful statuary and intricate carved decorations. Big imposing steps lead up from ground level and the Vatadage towers over the surrounding area. It's a but away from the busier parts of Polonnaruwa but its do serene and well worth a  all. A guide is vital though, you just won't get the same level of knowledge of the place from books or display boards.

We were surprised that no other tourists were here when we visited. Entrance is free but maybe it was empty because its quite far away from Polonnaruwa. We had a private driver so getting here was easy. The Vatadage is different from the one at Polonnaruwa's Sacred Quadrangle, but almost as nice. We were happy we made the trip out here.

Medirigiriya apparently functioned as a Buddhist monastery between the 3rd century BC and 13th century AD. The Monastery was subsequently destroyed by invaders from India. The ruins include the hauntingly beautiful Vatadage with its stone staircase, a Dagoba, two buildings that house beautiful Buddha statues and a hospital. Take a hat as the ruins are exposed to the sun and remove your footwear when walking into the ruins.

As you approach the Quadrangle - this is the building that stands out. This is reportedly the most beautiful ruin in SriLanka. It is a highly decorated  and ornate circular building, built on a number of levels. There are 4 entrances aligned to the cardinal points and each one has a Buddha facing out (one is only a ruin).  Compared to the outside , the inside is really plain.

With only a few tourists, this archaeological site is a very calm place to visite. The vatandage is more beautiful than the one in Polonnarwa. At so,e places you will have to take off your shoes and hats, as there are a few sacred places. On our way to the hospital we saw monkeys. Be careful at the hospital, the ants there attached me!
Medirigiriya Vatadage is what I call the mystic site which was used to meditate and listen to mystic chants for the kings.

It's about 30 km from polonnaruwa. Medirigiriya watadage is similar to the polonnaruwa watadage. The architecture is almost the same. The only thing to see in medirigiriya is the medirigiriya watadage. Not a very popular tourist attraction. You can see the archaeological ruins of an old temple complex, a hospital and an old urinal.

This one is close to the gate so it is very crowded. There are also a lot of people selling you touristic things. A wooded elephant can be bought for 50 rupees(at the sea side you will buy it with 450) I find it rather small for a city hall but it has it's charm

A visit through Polonnaruwa ruins would not be complete without visiting Medirigiriya Vatadage.  The Vatadage is an ancient structure dating back to the Kingdom of Polonnaruwa of Sri Lanka.  It is believed to have been built during the reign of Parakramabahu I to hold the Relic of the tooth of the Buddha or during the reign of Nissanka Malla of Polonnaruwa to hold the alms bowl used by the Buddha.  Both these venerated relics would have given the structure a great significance and importance at the time.  It is the best preserved example of a vatadage in the country and for that reason, just standing amongst the ruins so phenomenally preserved is amazing in itself. Everyone should be respectful for the dress code they don‚Äôt offer sarongs so best to take one yourself, and remove your hat.  Would visit again and recommend to others.
This is the remains of the old kingdom. The old Buddhist architecture structures ruins.A place to spend about an hour.
Must visited site, built on rocks and wot a stunning view from the site..located at Few km away from Medirigiriya town..ruins of kindom can be seen in this site..

Medirigiriya is located little out of the way from Polonnaruwa but not very far. However, the stupa at Medirigiriya is very unique (better and a bigger than the Vatadage in Polonnaruwa) and one of the best conserved. Therefore it is recommended to visit here. Medirigiriya is located little out of the way from Polonnaruwa but close by. However, the stupa at Medirigiriya is very unique (better and a bigger than the Vatadage in Polonnaruwa) and one of the best conserved. Therefore it is recommended to visit here. This monastery has a history since 3rd century BC. it's said that more than one king has contributed to this amazing place namely King Kanitta Thissa, King Agbo ii and king Sena ii from Anuradhapura kingdom as well as Parakramabahu the great from Polonnaruwa Kingdom. It is not clear which king built this, but was recorded as many kings renovated and extended the area. There had been a very modern hospital according to the Sri Lankan history and was destroyed by the Indian invasions by Kaliga Magha time to time. This is the part of Polonnaruwa ruin complex and one of the most remarkable objects were used as main temple and reliquaries. Since this is a Buddhist pilgrimage place better to wear proper attire and also you'll need to remove your shoes and hats prior enter some areas. Before  visiting it is advisable to read about the history or take a guide to visit this place since there is lot of hidden history. Protruding up into the sky, stone pillars that once held up a roof that protected a stupa built from bricks. The stupa is still there but now very small mound. Again shoes off. Try to visit at a cooler part of the day. This is the part of Polonnaruwa ruin complex and one of the most remarkable object used as main temple and reliquarium. It takes you back to ancient history. One should wonder what it would be like living in those days. In present days, one just enjoys what the past has to offer. Since it is a religious place of worship you will have to remove shoes within some small areas. It can be really hot, so sunglasses, a cap, and a water bottle would come handy. It is a marvellous construction. This is a monastery as well as an hospital according to the archaeological evidences.Protruding up into the sky, stone pillars that once held up a roof that protected a stupa built from bricks. The stupa is still there but now very small mound. The whole of Polonnaruwa is marvel to relish and relive the past. Every little detail in stone is enjoyable and it is quite impressive. This place is not frequent visit by tourists but it is worth watching definitely. Anyone who visits the country should visit this place.
The whole of Polonnaruwa is marvel to relish and relive the past. Every little detail in stone is enjoyable.
If you are visiting Polonnaruwa, please do make the time to include this site. We asked our driver to factor this in and were very glad we did. Absolutely stunning!
The pillars on this structure are pretty unique having a lotus shape end to it. Could have been pillars supporting a roof. A part of the Sacred Quadrangle.
We visited the place after our Polonnaruwa visit, we were the only on site, quiet impressive. Especially as not frequent visit by tourists, it makes the places more exclusive.

Medirigiriya is located little out of the way from Polonnaruwa but close by. However, the stupa at Medirigiriya is very unique (better and a bigger than the Vatadage in Polonnaruwa)  and one of the best conserved. Therefore it is recommended to visit here. Since it is a religious place of worship you will have to remove shoes within some small areas. It can be really hot, so sunglasses, a cap, and a water bottle would come handy!

I have visited Polonnaruwa, Somawathiya many times in my life. This is the first time I happen to visit this ancient rock temple. It is not clear which king built this, but was recorded as many kings renovated and extended the area. There had been a very modern hospital according to the Sri Lankan history and was destroyed by the indian invasions by Kaliga Magha time to time. Any one visiting I advise to read about the history or take a guide to visit this place since there is lot of hidden history. I read about this after visiting the place. Also another advise is to visit there early in the morning or once the sun goes down when its cool otherwise you can't think of climbing any steps cause it becomes very very hot during the day time.

This monastery has a history since 3rd century BC.... it's said that more than one king has contributed to this amazing place namely King Kanitta Thissa, King Agbo ii and king Sena ii from Anuradhapura kingdom as well as Parakramabahu the great from Polonnaruwa Kingdom... This is a monastery as well as an hospital according to the archeological evidences... Since this is a Buddhist pilgrimage place better to wear proper attire.. also you'll need to remove your shoes and hats prior enter some areas...

Protruding up into the sky, stone pillars that once held up a roof that protected a stupa built from bricks. The stupa is still there  but now very small mound. Again shoes off. Try to visit at a cooler part of the day..

Any one who visits the country should visit this place .its a marvelous  construction .as a Sinhalese i am very proud .invite all the people to visit this place in early morning or evening as the temperature is unbearable  .most of the people miss this place as it situated far from polonnaruwa archeological site .but its worth watching definitely
This is the part of Polonnaruwa ruin complex and one of the most remarkable object used as main temple and reliquarium.

I visited this place in the morning. The temperature was hot however the walk to view these ruins was great. It takes you back to ancient history. One should wonder what it would be like living in those days. In present days, one just enjoys what the past has to offer.
It's a very beautiful historical place. Architecture was sharp and unique.That is the cutest & valuable watadage in Sri Lanka.

Medirigirya Vatadage is a place where the ancient kings built a sthupa, with a roof built over it for the protection of the sthupa from the sun and rain. It was build during the Pollonnaruwa Kingdom, and more than 1900 years old. The Sthupa is built from bricks that are resting on a platform build from stones, and a set of stone pillars that are erected around the sthupa to hold the roof. Today though the roof cannot be seen, the pillars and the platform is still intact, whilst the sthupa is deteriorated, to a mound. In addition to the main sthupa, one has the opportunity of walking in the vast surrounding where you may see few smaller sthupa. It is recommended that one should visit the attraction early morning or late afternoon, since during the day time walking around the sthupa and the platform with no shoes is not of comfort with the stone heating up for the sun. In addition to the ruins, for those interested in wildlife, monkeys and birds can be seen, if you are patient enough.
Great historical and architecture site, this heritage is unique in the world, really impressive... impossible to miss it.

Medirigiriya might not be on the itinerary of most folk who visit Polonnaruwa. But it is well worth the time and effort. An impressive edifice, quite well-preserved and cared for. The explanatory boards and plaques provide useful information, adequate to satisfy most travelers; hence no need for a guide. Allocate about 2-3 hours of time for the average tour.

In Sri lanka there are three archeological sites (Vatadage in Polonnaruwa, Thiriyaya - north of Trincomalee and Medirigiriya) where circular style edifices are found. Out of these three, Medirigiriya stands out as a architecturally unique site with much of its support columns and structure still remaining perfectly. It is a large complex and a place that should never be missed.

Each one facing a different direction. 18 m in diameter this is an i pressive ruin with much detail still remaining. Each buddha had their own guards, and in pristine condition this must have been extremely impressive. Not to be missed.
There is a board on the side , where anyone can read and understand and no need to take a guide , try to start this site around 9 am so that you can come out noon .

This place is a fair drive outside Polonnaruwa but is astoundingly beautiful. Strangely when we went there were only 2 other people there, despite Polonnaruwa being packed out. There is no entrance charge, you simply walk a few hundred metres along a shady path from the car park, take your shoes off (take thick socks) and explore. The central vatadage has two complete rings of columns (from supporting long-gone roofs) and four beautiful buddhas pointing to the four points of the compass.
It is one of many interesting places in Polonnaruwa and you could spend a day taking in all the detail of the various exhibits.
My favourite place. Well worth the short trip out. Go there during sunset or sunrise for stunning lighting. Can't keep this off my wallpaper
A hall of stone pillars that took a lot of wealth and work to creat, still standing centuries after the wooden roofs and furnishing have weathered away.  Elaborate stone entrance.
Compared to Polonnaruwa this site is much more quiet. The location is a bit out of the way, but it is very quiet which gives it a special atmosphere.

There aren't many tourists here, you may be here solo. This is a highly recommended day trip if you are in Polonnaruwa and need more of what you have seen there. This is a really lovely place with wonderful photographic opportunities. There isn't much in the way of facilities at the actual site except a couple of tent cafe's selling soft drinks and chips. Take resources (Hat, sunblock, water) It's so delightful that you may want to picnic here. Directions from Anuradhapura. *Take the Anuradhapura-Polonawurra Road to Habarana and then to Minneriya Town (A11) *Take the Hingurakoda Road (B287) to Hingurakoda Town *When you cross the Railway lines at Hingurakoda Town, turn left onto Medirigiriya Road (B155) at the main intersection (look for the Clock Tower) *Continue onward (The (B155) becomes (B48) after a while) *Drive on, you‚Äôll see the sign for ‚ÄúVatadage‚Äù and a big car park on the right. *This is where you park and enter the Archeological Zone. If you are traveling from Polonnaruwa/Batticaloa *It‚Äôs the same principal. Turn off at Minneriya and it‚Äôs the same directions from there.
